channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Bollywood Superstar’s Movie Gets Tangled in Electoral Politics
item.description: Salman Khan has come under fire from Muslims, a big portion of his fan base, after his public appearances with Narendra Modi of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR

item.title: Venezuelan Leader Announces Expulsion of 3 U.S. Officials
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro, a focus of student-led protests in recent days, did not identify the consular officials, who he said had been visiting private universities in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Abbas, Talking to Israeli Students About Peace, Finds a Receptive Audience
item.description: The Palestinian president struck a conciliatory tone during a well-publicized meeting in the West Bank with about 300 students and youth leaders from Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas, left, struck a conciliatory tone as he met with Israeli students Sunday in Ramallah.

item.title: Merkel Backs Plan to Keep European Data in Europe
item.description: After the revelations of American spying, the German chancellor said she would raise the matter at a meeting with the French president this week.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Ben Aoun Journal: Tunisian B-Boys’ Biggest Battle: Keeping Youths From Extremism
item.description: In a small town, where some say many young people are drifting into drugs or even militancy, break dancing and a youth center offer alternatives.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nidhal Bouallagui, break-dancing in Ben Aoun, said Salafi leaders had become a magnet for the town’s aimless youths.

item.title: In Egypt, a Chasm Grows Between Young and Old
item.description: Many young Egyptians say the government’s heavy-handed reaction to protests has hampered their ability to establish a role in shaping the nation’s future.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The referendum was an alarm bell for them,” Shady el-Ghazaly Harb said of the government’s reaction to low youth turnout.

item.title: At Asia Air Show, Plenty of Competition for Sales of Drones
item.description: Military contractors from Austria, Australia, Israel, the United States and other countries showcased unmanned aerial vehicles throughout the week at the Singapore Airshow.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: An IAI Heron 1 drone, developed by an Israeli firm and operated by the Singapore Air Force, on display at the Singapore Airshow.

item.title: Always Room at the Inn for Another Medal
item.description: Norway’s Kjetil Jansrud won gold, Andrew Weibrecht was the surprise silver medalist and Bode Miller finished in a tie for bronze.
item.dc:creator: By BILL PENNINGTON
item.media:description: Bode Miller, who didn't think his time would be good enough for a medal, was emotional with his wife, Morgan Beck, after winning a bronze.

item.title: A Mad Dash for Salt Rescues Olympic Slopes
item.description: Soft snow threatened Alpine events at the Sochi Games, but a hastily arranged purchase from Switzerland of 24 tons of a large-grain variety of salt unavailable in Russia saved the day.
item.dc:creator: By SAM DOLNICK
item.media:description: A worker threw salt to prepare the track during the men's 4x10-kilometer cross-country relay on Sunday.

item.title: Turnabout in Bolivia as Economy Rises From Instability
item.description: With a growing economy, a reduced debt and an enviable rainy-day fund, Bolivia has become a nation whose fiscal policy is praised by international financial institutions.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A large market in El Alto, a working-class city in Bolivia. From colorful mansions to a proliferation of bakeries, there are signs that many have extra cash to spend.

item.title: Protesters Vacate Kiev’s City Hall in Deal for Amnesty
item.description: As they left the building that they had occupied for more than two months, the protesters said they would seize it again if the authorities did not drop all charges against political activists.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Opposition supporters left City Hall in Kiev on Sunday.

item.title: Islamist Militants Kill Scores in Remote Northeast Nigeria
item.description: Gunmen from the militant group Boko Haram surrounded the village of Izge, spraying it with bullets, setting off explosions and burning down houses, witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: A Berlusconi Reminder as Italy Faces Another Unelected Premier
item.description: Matteo Renzi will become the prime minister and has promised to change election laws so that voters can have a clearer say about who becomes premier in the future.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Matteo Renzi, left, in Florence on Sunday, is to become, at 39, Italy’s youngest prime minister. He is called the Demolisher.

item.title: Lens Blog: The World’s Best (Unaltered) Photos
item.description: World Press Photo announced the winners of its 2013 contest while its judges lamented the proliferation of digital alterations, which disqualified several top contenders.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: A cluster of countries in Central America — Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador — makes up one of the most violent regions in the world. In many cases, clothes that are found become the only means to identify victims, like this woman's clothing found at a sugar plantation in Apopa, San Salvador. She was 17 or 18 years old. First place, daily life stories.

item.title: Transgender Former Member of Italian Parliament Detained in Sochi
item.description: Vladimir Luxuria was detained by Russian authorities Sunday after holding up a sign that said, “Gay is OK,” in the Olympic Park, according to the leader of an Italian gay rights group.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Kerry Blames Syrian Government for Deadlocked Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry’s statement appeared aimed at keeping up the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad, and to bolster the hope that a political settlement might be reached.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Bombing of Tourist Bus Kills at Least Three in Sinai
item.description: The cause of the explosion was not certain, but it raised fears that Egyptian militants were expanding their campaign against the security services to include civilians.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Smoke rose Sunday from a tourist bus in a resort town in Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula.

item.title: Author Resigned to Ill Fate of Book in India
item.description: The recall and destruction in India of Wendy Doniger’s book “The Hindus: An Alternative History” settled a legal case and didn’t surprise the author.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN WILLIAMS
item.media:description: Wendy Doniger said she wrote about how “Hinduism has dealt with pluralism.”

item.title: Obama Condemns Uganda’s Tough Antigay Measure
item.description: After the Ugandan president signaled that he was likely to sign a bill to criminalize homosexuality, President Obama on Sunday warned that the measure could harm ties with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH WHEATON

item.title: Kerry Implores Indonesia on Climate Change Peril
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Indonesia’s failure to act would jeopardize its resources, damage its economy and put much of the capital under water.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: South Africans in Mine Rescued and Then Arrested
item.description: The miners were working illegally in an abandoned shaft near Johannesburg, and they told rescuers that more than 200 others were trapped underground, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
item.media:description: Rescue workers tried to free miners who became trapped while working illegally in an old gold-mine shaft in Benoni, South Africa, on Sunday.

item.title: More Than 200 South African Miners Are Trapped
item.description: Rescuers on Sunday were trying to reach the illegal miners trapped in an abandoned gold shaft in a suburb east of Johannesburg, an emergency services spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Iraqi Cleric Says Again He’ll Quit Politics
item.description: Moktada al-Sadr, who became one of Iraq’s most popular political leaders, has made such announcements before, but his statement added uncertainty to the political situation in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Difficult Day for South Koreans as Native Son Wins Gold, for Russia
item.description: Viktor Ahn, formerly Ahn Hyun-soo, was a celebrated speed skater in South Korea — until circumstances changed.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 18 Feared Dead in Nepalese Air Crash
item.description: An official at the airport in Katmandu, the capital, blamed bad weather for the crash, saying it had been snowing for much of the day.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Relatives of victims gathered outside the Airlines Operation Complex in Kathmandu, Nepal, after the plane crash.
